Award.AwardTitle: CRC: Center for Innovative Research on Cyberlearning (CIRCL)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cyberlearning Resource Center (CRC) has responsibility for promoting integrative collaboration among cyberlearning grantees (across NSF programs); synthesis and national dissemination of cyberlearning findings, technologies, models, materials, and best practices; creating a national presence for Cyberlearning; helping the disparate Cyberlearning research and development communities coordinate efforts to build capacity; and providing infrastructure (technological and social) for supporting these efforts. Monitored through the Cyberlearning: Transforming Education program, the CRC serves as a resource for all NSF grantees and programs with cyberlearning components, helping to promote synergy and integrate projects across NSF's cyberlearning investments.

Among society's central challenges are amplifying, expanding, and transforming opportunities people have for learning and more effectively drawing in, motivating, and engaging young learners. Engaging actively as a citizen and productively in the workforce requires understanding a broad variety of concepts and possessing the ability to collaborate, learn, solve problems, and make decisions. Whether learning is facilitated in school or out of school, and whether learners are youngsters or adults, to develop such knowledge and capabilities, learners must be motivated to learn, actively engage over the long term in learning activities, and put forth sustained cognitive and social effort. Consistent with NSF's mission and strategic plan, a variety of programs at NSF invest in research aimed towards achieving these goals. In support of this important thematic thrust, the Cyberlearning Resource Center works with researchers and NSF program officers to identify and disseminate findings from across programs and projects; develop ways to broker productive partnerships and collaborations; convene meetings for purposes of envisioning the future, integrating findings, and building capacity,; and monitor the cyberlearning portfolio and its influences and impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For eight years, our team at the Center for Innovative Research in Cyberlearning (CIRCL; circlcenter.org) had the privilege of working with a dynamic community of researchers who were awarded grants by the National Science Foundation to explore the future of learning with emerging technologies. We worked across separate projects to synthesize the field's progress, for example, by publishing the "Cyberlearning Community Report." We analyzed the field's work by theme, identifying how the research has evolved and highlighting future priorities; see our publication "Ambitious Mashups: Reflections on a Decade of Cyberlearning Research." We convened the field around challenging research issues of high interest to the public and policymakers that are often too broad for any one project to address; see our report on a summit of NSF workshops as well as our forthcoming report "AI and the Future of Learning." We contributed to policy documents of national importance, such as the National Educational Technology Plan, by translating insights from the scientific community for inclusion in documents that reach broader audiences.

Intellectual Merit

CIRCL served the cyberlearning research community by helping leaders in the field to tackle big issues together and reach a broader audience. The field of cyberlearning is defined by strong attention to both computer science and learning sciences perspectives, an orientation to the future of learning, a commitment to interdisciplinary work, and dedication to considering how the future of learning could be more equitable. With the community, we charted novel and advanced designs for learning that are emerging as new technologies come into play (e.g. natural language processing, artificial learning and teaching agents, social robots, learning analytics, etc.). We also tracked and reported on the areas of learning theory that researchers are finding most powerful in investigating innovations for learning (e.g. embodied cognition, collaborative learning, agency and identity, cross-context learning). Most importantly, we helped the field to reflect on the kinds of scientific work that are generating the most progress. For example, we noticed strong progress among projects that investigate "ambitious mashups" where multiple novel technologies come together in an innovative design for learning. We also highlighted multi-model learning analytics as an important area in which advances in research methods are occurring, in ways that could accelerate scientific progress broadly.

Broader Impacts

CIRCL realized broader impacts in three ways. First, we accelerated sharing of scientific information within the cyberlearning research field, enabling investigators to more rapidly build on each other's advances. For example, we launched a Rapid Community Report series to speed publication of emerging insights. We hosted six annual convenings (2012-19) for the cyberlearning community, engaging approximately 200 participants in each meeting to present their work, identify issues of common interest, discuss tensions that arise as research teams expand the boundaries of learning, and ignite collective efforts among participants. We organized a summit that brought together NSF-funded workshop leaders to discuss cross-cutting findings, insights, and recommendations for the next decade of research and development challenges. We facilitated regular communication in the field via a newsletter, social media feed and frequently updated website.

Second, we cultivated relationships. Through expertise exchanges, we helped investigators learn about and leverage each other's scientific expertise. Through "buddy" activities, we actively sought to increase the diversity of the field, for example, inviting researchers at HBCUs to engage with cyberlearning researchers. We connected the U.S.-based cyberlearning field to parallel efforts in Europe, called Technology-Enhanced Learning. We brokered expertise so that project leaders could access scientific knowledge that their project needed and was beyond their own team's strengths. We structured our convenings to enable participants to join together in teams that would go beyond the short-term event. 

Third, we amplified dissemination and outreach. Building on insights of the field, we co-authored an "Innovative Pedagogy" report that reached a worldwide audience of over 75,000 downloads. We facilitated the presentation of cyberlearning projects in the video showcase, an event attended by more than 50,000 researchers, educators, and innovators each year. We organized an event to enable experts in Artificial Intelligence to directly inform policy leaders at the U.S. Department of Education about their research. We facilitated contributions from cyberlearning researchers to national policy documents, like the National Educational Technology Plan.

Conclusion

Technology will deeply influence how learning happens in the future. The challenges are broader and deeper than any single research project could address on its own. Further, the pace of research does not always keep up with the rapid evolution of technology and ever more challenging issues of diversity, equity, and inclusion in learning. By building a community across related projects, finding opportunities for synergy, and amplifying communication about designs, insights, and findings, this center contributed to society's preparation for effective and equitable learning with future technologies.
